author: By Jennifer Medina
title: The Look, and Scent, of the Surreal
description: Jennifer Medina, a political reporter who lives in Los Angeles, writes about a reporting trip that took her to both the Palisades and Eaton fire zones.
content: To truly take in the enormity, it helps to get up close.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Pardons and Populism: Trump’s First Day Back in the White House
description: The message President Trump sent in his inaugural address, and the actions he took in his first hours.
content: Warning: This episode contains strong language.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson
title: Trump’s Proposed Tariff Agency Raises Questions, and Confusion, for Experts
description: President Trump wants an External Revenue Service to collect tariffs on imports. One trade expert said the move may be “more branding than substance.”
content: President Trump has promised to generate a “massive” amount of revenue with tariffs on foreign products, an amount so big that the president said he would create a new agency — the External Revenue Service — to handle collecting the money.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: Southport Killings Are a New Kind of Terrorism, U.K. Prime Minister Says
description: After a teenager admitted murdering three girls at a dance class, Keir Starmer said people were being radicalized into violence for its own sake and terrorism laws might need to change.
content: Britain faces a new and dangerous form of extremism, Prime Minister Keir Starmer said on Tuesday, warning that loners and misfits were being radicalized by “a tidal wave of violence freely available online.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Questions Prosecutors’ Focus on Sex in Capital Case
description: The court instructed an appeals court to reconsider whether lurid evidence tainted the trial of Brenda Andrew, the only woman on Oklahoma’s death row.
content: The Supreme Court on Tuesday gave the only woman on death row in Oklahoma a fresh opportunity to challenge her sentence and conviction, saying that prosecutors may have violated her right to a fair trial by introducing lurid evidence about her sexual activities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By German Lopez
title: Trump’s First Day Back
description: We’re covering President Trump’s inauguration, executive orders and pardons.
content: A president’s second swearing-in is sometimes a low-energy affair — a continuation of the norm. But President Trump signaled yesterday that he was returning with an agenda that is both more sweeping and better vetted than that of his first term.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Dias and Tim Balk
title: Who Is Mariann Edgar Budde, the Bishop Who Made a Plea to Trump?
description: The first woman to serve as the spiritual leader of the Episcopal Diocese of Washington, Bishop Budde had a message for President Trump during his first term, too.
content: Bishop Mariann Edgar Budde, whose direct appeal to President Trump for mercy on behalf of immigrants and the L.G.B.T.Q. community made headlines on Tuesday, was also publicly critical of Mr. Trump during his first term.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By M. Gessen
title: I Spent Trump’s Inauguration in Ukraine. This Is What I Saw.
description: “And Panama!” a Ukrainian military analyst said. “What did calm, peaceful Panama do?”
content: On the day of Donald Trump’s second inauguration, an air raid was in effect in Odesa for much of the afternoon. People went about their business. Street vendors continued selling coffee. Trams kept running. At Pryvoz, the mammoth farmers’ (and everything else) market, electricity went out for a while, but that seemed to have no effect on the pace of commerce; if it was slow, that was because it was a Monday. In the two years and 11 months since Russia launched its full-scale invasion of Ukraine, Odesa has gone through stages: months of shock and fear, followed by something akin to denial and, finally, adaptation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mia Leimkuhler
title: Just Think of the Leftovers
description: Meatballs, scallion chicken and cauliflower adobo are quick and delicious dinners, but they really shine when repurposed or reheated.
content: Hi, everyone! Mia here, filling in for Emily today.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Renard
title: David Lynch’s Enchanting Sound Worlds
description: Music played a huge role in defining the filmmaker’s distinctive atmosphere on the big and small screens. Hear 13 examples.
content: David Lynch, the filmmaker whose death at 78 was announced Thursday, was known for his surreal visions that mix the macabre with the everyday. And as early as his very first feature, the 1977 midnight movie “Eraserhead,” sound played a huge role in achieving those unsettling effects — Lynch and the sound designer Alan R. Splet populated that film’s industrial urban hell with hums, low roars and rumbles, crackling electricity and grinding gears. (They also paused the action to present an unusual performance — more on that later — in a move that would become something of a Lynch trademark.)
source.name: The New York Times

title: Red Words

title: Trump declared an emergency at the southern border. Here’s what that means.
description: Invoking presidential emergency powers gives the president the ability to go around Congress and unlock federal funding to crack down at the border.
content: President Trump declared a national emergency at the U.S.-Mexico border on Monday, invoking special presidential powers that allow him to unilaterally unlock federal funding for border wall construction and potentially to deploy the military and National Guard to the border.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush
title: Trump Crushes Justice Department’s Biggest Investigation In an Instant
description: President Trump’s pardons in the Jan. 6 case abruptly ended the most complex investigation in U.S. history. It also raised questions about what he will do next against a department he has said is full of his enemies.
content: The effort to prosecute the violent mob that ransacked the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, and the leaders of far-right groups who egged them on, represented the biggest and most logistically complex investigation in the history of the Justice Department.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cecilia Kang and Cade Metz
title: Trump Announces $100 Billion A.I. Initiative
description: OpenAI, Oracle and SoftBank formed a new joint venture called Stargate to invest in data centers, building on major U.S. investments in the technology.
content: President Trump on Tuesday announced a joint venture between OpenAI, SoftBank and Oracle to create at least $100 billion in computing infrastructure to power artificial intelligence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush and Adam Goldman
title: Senate Questionnaire Sheds Light on F.B.I. Pick’s Early Years
description: In the form, Kash Patel said he had participated in an American Bar Association program that promotes diversity. He also played down his role in the Benghazi investigation.
content: Kash Patel, the Trump loyalist tapped to run the F.B.I., has provided fresh details about his life — including legal work on behalf of a human trafficker, membership in an exclusive Las Vegas club and participation in a diversity-and-inclusion program, in new documents sent to lawmakers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Esther Zuckerman
title: ‘Prime Target’ Is a Charming Popcorn Thriller
description: Don’t think overly hard about the premise. Just enjoy the constant cliffhangers and beautiful people.
content: “Prime Target,” an eight-episode thriller premiering Wednesday on Apple TV+, has the juicy vibe of a novel you might pick up at an airport and rip through in a single flight. It has an outlandish premise, beautiful people, and it ends on a cliffhanger every episode.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Friedman and Derek Arthur
title: Thomas Friedman: The Global Challenges Facing Trump
description: The columnist on why the president is facing a rare moment of opportunity in the Middle East.
content: The Times columnist Thomas Friedman says this is a rare moment “when everything in the Middle East is in play and everything is possible.” In this episode of “The Opinions,” he speaks with the Times editor Dan Wakin about the forces brewing in the Middle East, what he expects of the relationship between Benjamin Netanyahu and Donald Trump and the one gig he would give up his column to do.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Goldman, Carol Rosenberg and Julian E. Barnes
title: 2 Americans Held in Afghanistan Are Freed in Prisoner Swap
description: In exchange, the Biden administration released an Afghan man convicted on narcotics charges in 2008.
content: In one of its final acts, the Biden administration secured the release of two Americans held in Afghanistan in a prisoner swap for a Taliban member imprisoned in the United States on narcotics charges.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas B. Edsall
title: The Right Is Winning the Battle for Hearts and Minds
description: The full-scale assault by the conservative movement on liberal domination of the nation’s culture has begun to deliver key victories.
content: The full-scale assault by the conservative movement on liberal domination of the nation’s culture has begun to deliver key victories.

title: Trump Starts Immigration Crackdown, Enlisting the Military and Testing the Law

content: Follow live updates on the start of the Trump administration.

title: Trump Withdraws U.S. From World Health Organization
description: Public health experts say U.S. withdrawal from the W.H.O. would undermine the nation’s standing as a global health leader and make it harder to fight the next pandemic.
content: President Trump moved quickly on Monday to withdraw the United States from the World Health Organization, a move that public health experts say will undermine the nation’s standing as a global health leader and make it harder to fight the next pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Poniewozik
title: Trump Returns, and So Does His TV Spectacle
description: The president’s second inauguration began with somber pageantry and ended with a reality-TV document signing.
content: Donald J. Trump has always tried to choose his own stage settings, be it looming over a built-for-TV boardroom in “The Apprentice” or descending down the Trump Tower escalator in 2015. For his second inauguration, nature did the choosing for him: Subfreezing weather in Washington prompted the event to move indoors, to the Rotunda of the U.S. Capitol.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Bailey
title: ‘Problemista,’ ‘Stress Positions’ and More Streaming Gems
description: A pair of inventive comedies lead off this month’s exploration of the hidden discoveries on your subscription streaming services.
content: The comedian Julio Torres writes, directs and stars in this gleefully absurd, semi-surreal combination of outsider comedy and New York art world satire. The protagonist Alejandro, like Torres, hails from El Salvador, coming to America with dreams of success as a toymaker (his emo-tinged inventions are among the picture’s running comic highlights), but he finds himself trapped in the bureaucratic maze of work visas, immigration sponsorship and under- the-table pay. His makeshift solution is a thankless job helping an art critic (a gloriously unhinged Tilda Swinton) assemble the works of her cryogenically frozen husband (RZA). Torres’s perceptive screenplay scores laughs in manners grand and small, from elaborate fantasy sequences to the deeply relatable frustrations of a boss’s attachment to outdated software. He stages his comic sequences with visual flair — a too-rare quality these days — while smuggling in surprisingly poignant moments of truth and wisdom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael S. Schmidt and Mark Mazzetti
title: A Trump Executive Order Sets Out What Could Be a Road Map for Retribution
description: The order is titled “Ending the Weaponization of the Federal Government,” but it asserts that the Biden administration might have acted illegally and directs agencies to seek evidence.
content: Since his election victory, President Trump has said he would not seek retribution against his perceived enemies. “I’m not looking to go into the past,” he said last month on NBC’s “Meet the Press.” “Retribution will be through success.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum
title: A Big Day for Fox News, but TV Ratings Were Down for Trump Speech
description: A peak of 34.4 million people tuned in live to watch the president’s lunchtime swearing-in on the major TV networks, according to Nielsen.
content: Fox News was far and away the most-watched TV network during President Trump’s inauguration on Monday, a sign of both the channel’s dominance in cable news and the overall drop in Americans who rely on television to keep up on current events.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Ismay
title: Admiral Fagan Is Fired as Coast Guard Commandant
description: The first woman to lead a branch of the armed forces was relieved of command within 24 hours of President Trump’s inauguration.
content: The Trump administration fired the commandant of the U.S. Coast Guard, Adm. Linda L. Fagan, within 24 hours of President Trump’s inauguration. The admiral, who was sworn in as the service chief on June 1, 2022, was the first female officer to lead a branch of the American armed forces.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Correal and Farnaz Fassihi
title: Panama Alerts United Nations to Trump’s Inaugural Remarks
description: On Monday, President Trump said of the Panama Canal, “We’re taking it back.” The letter from Panama cited articles of the U.N. charter that prohibit member states from using threats and force.
content: Panama submitted a formal letter to U.N. Secretary General António Guterres and the U.N. Security Council on Monday, rejecting comments that President Trump made about reclaiming the Panama Canal during his inauguration speech.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Correal and Daniele Volpe
title: How One Country Plans to Resettle Planeloads of Deportees from the U.S.
description: The case of Guatemala reveals how President Trump’s promised sweeps could change life outside the United States, too.
content: Carlos Navarro was eating takeout outside a restaurant in Virginia recently when immigration officers apprehended him and said there was an order for his removal from the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eileen Sullivan
title: How Trump’s Plan to Label Some Drug Cartels ‘Terrorists’ Would Work
description: His administration would have more power to impose economic penalties and travel restrictions, and potentially even take military action inside foreign countries.
content: President Trump’s call for the State Department to start the process of designating certain cartels as global terrorists and foreign terrorist organizations could give his administration more power to impose economic penalties, travel restrictions and potentially even take military action inside foreign nations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andy Newman
title: New Jersey’s Governor Asks Trump to Move Swiftly on Congestion Pricing
description: Gov. Phil Murphy wrote a letter to the president saying that the surcharge on drivers entering Manhattan’s busiest area was a “disaster” for commuters and residents in his state.
content: New Jersey’s Democratic governor, Philip D. Murphy, asked President Trump on Monday to re-examine New York’s congestion pricing program, which is charging drivers $9 to enter Manhattan’s central business district and which his state had unsuccessfully sued to block.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Trump Commutes Sentence of Stewart Rhodes, Founder of Oath Keepers Militia
description: The move, in effect, validated the far-right leader’s defiant claim that his criminal prosecution was a kind of political persecution.
content: When Stewart Rhodes, the founder of the Oath Keepers militia, appeared in court in 2023 to be sentenced on sedition charges stemming from the storming of the Capitol, he angrily declared himself a “political prisoner,” echoing language that President Trump has also used to describe those involved with the events of Jan. 6, 2021.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex C. Park
title: Want an Authentic Travel Experience? Try McDonald’s.
description: It’s a much realer version of the supposed authenticity we so often seek.
content: On a recent trip to Tokyo, I stopped at a suburban McDonald’s and spoke with a few older patrons. I was interested in their memories of the brand’s Japanese debut in 1971. Between sips of coffee, a man in his 70s told us that he remembered it vividly: It was around the time that Yukio Mishima, then the nation’s most celebrated writer and a champion of Japanese imperialism, committed suicide after a failed coup. One era was ending, another was beginning, and the transition was marked by the arrival of an American restaurant radically different from anything they had ever seen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laurie Gwen Shapiro
title: John Lennon Came to My School When I Was 8. Or Did I Imagine It?
description: A story of hazy memories, a reluctant rock star and a special day in 1973. Or was it 1974?
content: One morning in the mid-1970s, a solemn announcement came over the intercom at Friends Seminary: “Noted person John Lennon is now in the meetinghouse. Walk, don’t run.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mattathias Schwartz and Mike Baker
title: Twenty-two States Sue to Stop Trump’s Birthright Citizenship Order
description: The lawsuit to block the president’s executive order is the first salvo in what is likely to be a long-running legal fight over immigration policy.
content: Attorneys general from 22 states sued President Trump in two federal district courts on Tuesday to block an executive order that refuses to recognize the U.S.-born children of unauthorized immigrants as citizens, the opening salvo in what promises to be a long legal battle over the Trump administration’s immigration policies.
source.name: The New York Times

description: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, January 21, 2025
content: “From this moment on, America’s decline is over.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wilson and Chelsia Rose Marcius
title: The Voices in His Head Would Not Stop. Then a Boy Was Stabbed to Death.
description: Waldo Mejia’s psyche had been showing cracks, a longtime friend said. Now he is charged with killing 14-year-old Caleb Rijos at random.
content: Waldo Mejia, living in the Bronx, was in his early 20s when he told one of his oldest friends about the voices in his head. He seemed surprised at what they were ordering, and moreover, at how he so readily obeyed.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Billionaires’ Row at the Inauguration
description: The sight of Jeff Bezos, Mark Zuckerberg and others at President Trump’s swearing-in was another sign of how business is adapting to a new Washington.
content: In a stark display of money and power, the three wealthiest men on the planet lined up on Monday in the Capitol Rotunda to witness Donald Trump being sworn in as the 47th president.
source.name: The New York Times

source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Pitt’s Offers Fried Saltines and Country Captain in Red Hook
description: Periyali becomes Opto, Nerina opens a location in Brooklyn and more restaurant news.
content: Exploring the scrapbook of his Eastern European heritage led the chef Jeremy Salamon to serve chilled borscht and crispy schmaltz potatoes at Agi’s Counter, his busy Crown Heights, Brooklyn, spot. His new restaurant, bearing a childhood nickname and done with a touch of kitsch, is ensconced in the former Fort Defiance space. Its inspiration looks elsewhere, both locally and to North Carolina, where he cooked and seems to have picked up an obsession for saltines, fried or not. He has come up with pickled shrimp with oyster mayo, pimento cheese made with Gouda, fried Country Captain poussin, swordfish au poivre, a mutton chop with Keens Steakhouse as a likely inspiration, and a dessert soufflé tasting like pancakes. There’s also a clever kid’s menu.
source.name: The New York Times

title: What Trump’s Pledge to Plant the U.S. Flag on Mars Really Means
description: The president’s Inaugural Address linked landing on the Red Planet with Manifest Destiny, but left many of the specifics unclear.
content: During his Inaugural Address on Monday, President Donald J. Trump again promised to launch American astronauts to Mars.

title: How Trump’s Department of Government Efficiency Will Work
description: The structure and goals of the cost-cutting effort have changed over the past 10 weeks. Here’s how.
content: With the official establishment on Monday of President Trump’s closely watched effort to slash federal spending — which he has called the Department of Government Efficiency — some key information was revealed, including details about how the group will be structured and a new focus on modernizing technology.

content: President Trump on Monday ordered his administration to gut policies instituted under the Biden administration to prevent sex discrimination and protect transgender Americans, and dismantle federal programs that promote diversity, equity and inclusion.

content: My mother-in-law, Barbara Lipska, briefly lost her mind. I’m not being cute. Back in 2015, Barbara experienced severe cognitive impairment that, in layman’s terms, might be called insanity.

source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: Behind Killings at Girls’ Dance Class in U.K., a Boy Obsessed With Death

title: Trump’s V.A. Pick Says He’ll Protect Veterans’ Ability to Seek Outside Care
description: Doug Collins, chosen by President Trump to lead the Veterans Affairs Department, does not have a traditional résumé for V.A. secretary, but he fits the mold of a Trump loyalist.
content: Former Representative Doug Collins, President Trump’s nominee to lead the Veterans Affairs Department, told lawmakers in a confirmation hearing on Tuesday that he would defend a program that allows veterans to seek health services outside the V.A. medical system.

description: The measure, which increases deportations for undocumented migrants charged with crimes, is likely to be the first bill to reach President Trump’s desk. It must pass one more House vote to clear Congress.
content: The Senate on Monday approved a bill that would mandate detentions and potential deportations for undocumented migrants charged with certain crimes, setting it on a glide path to clear Congress this week and be signed by President Trump.

author: By Wilson Wong

description: Hilary Mantel’s “The Mirror and the Light,” a new “Bridget Jones” and Michael Bond’s Paddington Bear series are some of this year’s most anticipated adaptations.
content: New Year, new reading goals. It’s that season again when anything feels possible: Maybe this is the year you’ll finally tackle that dust-laden copy of “Infinite Jest” sitting on your shelf, or earn your “I finished ‘The Power Broker’” mug. And for binge watchers, it’s also the perfect chance to study up by diving into the books that are being adapted into movies and TV shows in 2025. author: By Austyn Gaffney

content: The unusual gust of frigid air extending down from the North Pole has brought the first-ever blizzard warning to southern Louisiana and grounded flights in Houston. The cold spell could blast the country with heavy snowfall from the Northeast down to the Gulf Coast this week.

title: Trump Moves to End Entry Program for Migrants From 4 Nations
description: The president sought to end a program that allowed migrants fleeing Cuba, Nicaragua, Venezuela and Haiti to fly into the United States and remain in the country for up to two years.

content: With winter weather striking the Southeastern United States on Tuesday and blanketing several states with snow and ice, travel via plane, train or car has become challenging.

author: By Jeffrey Toobin
title: Trump Just Pardoned Himself
description: Because presidents exercise such unfettered discretion in granting clemency, these actions provide useful insights into their true character.
content: At a campaign event shortly before the November election, President Trump gave an answer that offers the best explanation for the pardons he announced on Monday. Asked at a Univision town hall about the riot by his supporters at the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, he said, “There were no guns down there. We didn’t have guns.”

content: Jeff Torborg, an unassuming baseball lifer who caught three no-hitters, including Sandy Koufax’s perfect game in 1965, and as a manager revived the Chicago White Sox but flopped spectacularly with the New York Mets, died on Sunday in Port Orange, Fla. He was 83.

title: Judges Begin Freeing Jan. 6 Defendants and Dismissing Their Cases
description: Two prominent far-right extremists with central roles in the Capitol attack, Enrique Tarrio of the Proud Boys and Stewart Rhodes of the Oath Keepers militia, have been set free.

title: Trump Revokes John Bolton’s Secret Service Protection
description: President Joseph R. Biden Jr. had granted Bolton and another Trump national security adviser protection in 2021 after threats from Iran.

source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs, Tim Balk and Erica L. Green
title: Bishop Asks Trump to ‘Have Mercy’ on Immigrants and Gay Children
description: The direct appeal to President Trump on the first full day of his term was a remarkable moment at a National Cathedral event that traditionally has not been political.

title: A Day of Triumph, Jubilation and Gloating in Washington

source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Goldberg
title: C.E.O.s, and President Trump, Want Workers Back in the Office
description: Amazon, JPMorgan and others have been telling their employees that remote work is over. Now federal employees have been ordered to come to work in person, too.

title: They’ve Never Seen Snow Like This Before. They Wanted to Make the Most of It.
description: Snowfall along the Gulf Coast is rare. So, the powder on Tuesday inspired plenty of excitement and delight.
content: In the Ninth Ward of New Orleans on Tuesday, levees built to hold the Mississippi River at bay suddenly provided the perfect slope for sledding. source.name: The New York Times

description: President Trump’s wave of executive orders yesterday sent an undeniable signal to the world about the United States’ role in fighting climate change.

description: President Trump, who has criticized refugee resettlement, moved on his first day in office to suspend the decades-old program to admit persecuted people to the United States.

content: Israeli security forces on Tuesday embarked on a military operation in Jenin, a Palestinian city in the Israeli-occupied West Bank, as Israel turned its focus to an area seen as a hotbed of militancy just days after a temporary cease-fire took hold in Gaza.

Trump, in one of his first official acts, issued a sweeping grant of clemency on Monday to all of the nearly 1,600 people charged in connection with the attack on the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, issuing pardons to most of the defendants and commuting the sentences of 14 members of the Proud Boys and Oath Keepers militia, most of whom were convicted of seditious conspiracy.

title: Ex-Proud Boys Leader, Pardoned by Trump, Helped Initiate Capitol Riot
description: Until President Trump’s pardon, Enrique Tarrio was serving a 22-year prison term, the longest sentence handed down to any of the nearly 1,600 people charged in connection with Jan. 6.
content: By including Enrique Tarrio, the former leader of the Proud Boys, in his extraordinary pardons for the events of Jan. 6, 2021, President Trump granted clemency on Monday to a man whom prosecutors have described as a savvy, street-fighting extremist who helped his compatriots in “Trump’s army” initiate an assault on the Capitol.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette and Jack Ewing
title: Automakers Brace for Impact of Trump Tariff Plan for Canada and Mexico
description: North American car companies have operated across borders for three decades. Tariffs would raise prices and cost jobs in the short run, analysts say.
content: Automakers ship billions of dollars’ worth of vehicles and parts across the U.S. borders with Canada and Mexico every day. President Trump’s plan for 25 percent tariffs on imports from those countries could severely disrupt those operations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion No. 591
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Wednesday, Jan. 22, 2025.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacob Gallagher
title: Fresh Off ‘Severance,’ John Turturro Tries Modeling
description: With a Turturro cameo and a very surreal set, Zegna’s latest presentation brought to mind the hit Apple TV show. Though the clothes were far from corporate.
content: When John Turturro saw that the setting for Zegna’s runway show here was a grassy knoll, he wondered if he’d fallen into an Italian wormhole and landed back on the set of “Severance.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Joel Paley, Writer of ‘Ruthless,’ an Off Broadway Hit, Dies at 69
description: The show, with music by Marvin Laird, portrayed a schoolgirl’s murderous theatrical ambition. Paley also performed in the parody dance group Les Ballets Trockadero.
content: Joel Paley, a dancer, playwright and director who wrote the book and lyrics for “Ruthless!,” an award-winning Off Broadway musical about an ambitious girl who will do anything — including murder her rival — to star in a grade school show, died on Jan. 11 in Milford, Conn. He was 69.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jess Bidgood
title: Trump Promises Americans the Moon (Well, Mars)
description: Donald Trump’s pledge-filled speech made him sound like a candidate trying to run up the score.
content: Donald Trump spent much of the last two years promising that catastrophe would befall the nation if he were to lose the presidential election: World War III. An economic “blood bath.” America practically ceasing to exist.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Rush
title: Did Christopher Columbus Jump-Start the Climate Crisis?
description: In “Dark Laboratory,” Tao Leigh Goffe traces the origins of global environmental collapse to the explorer’s conquest of the Caribbean.
content: The slow-motion disaster that is climate change started with our unearthing long-buried organic matter and lighting it aflame, which released particles into the atmosphere that hold warmth. This is the story we tell ourselves about a central cause of our warming planet. But what if slowing down the climate change juggernaut has proved so difficult in part because we talk about the problem all wrong? Tao Leigh Goffe’s “Dark Laboratory: On Columbus, the Caribbean, and the Origins of the Climate Crisis” argues that current scientific discourse obscures the racist roots of our existential predicament while also overlooking potential strategies of repair and endurance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Judge Stops Justice Dept. From Releasing Report on Trump Documents Case
description: Judge Aileen M. Cannon said prosecutors should not be allowed to share the report outside the Justice Department, adding that it contained information that had not been made public.
content: A federal judge in Florida stopped the Justice Department on Tuesday from releasing to Congress a potentially damning section of a report by the former special counsel, Jack Smith, detailing his lengthy investigation of President Trump’s mishandling of classified documents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Greg Grandin
title: Trump Dreams of a New American Empire
description: He is tapping into a vision of a United States that is forever growing, forever moving outward.
content: Donald Trump won the White House twice on a promise to close the border. Now he waxes poetic about reopening the frontier — whose “spirit,” he said yesterday in his second Inaugural Address, “is written into our hearts.” This month, he talked about buying Greenland from Denmark, annexing Canada, retaking the Panama Canal and renaming the Gulf of Mexico the Gulf of America. “What a beautiful name,” Mr. Trump said, pronouncing the phrase with a decided stress on its last syllable: A-mer-i-CA, not A-MER-i-ca.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Sperling
title: Netflix Adds 19 Million Subscribers in Latest Quarter
description: The company said those results were buoyed by programming in recent months that exceeded internal expectations.
content: Netflix ended 2024 with 302 million global subscribers and an annual operating income exceeding $10 billion for the first time in the company’s history, the streaming giant said on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora
title: As Trump Takes Office, Zelensky Urges Europe to Stand Firm Against Russia
description: Speaking a day after Trump’s inauguration, Ukraine’s president told world leaders at Davos that Europe needs to remain united and “learn how to take care of itself.”
content: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine said at the World Economic Forum on Tuesday that it was time for Europe to stand strong and remain united as the United States installs a new president skeptical of global alliances and continued aid to Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: What 7 Americans Thought About Trump’s Inauguration Speech
description: We’ll be regularly checking in with this group of people during President Trump’s first 100 days in office. Here’s what they thought on Day 1.
content: As Donald J. Trump takes office once again, he will represent millions who enthusiastically support him, millions who forcefully oppose him and, perhaps most critically, millions in between.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Kim
title: A Nobel Laureate Who Mines Her Country’s Nightmares, and Her Own
description: Han Kang’s latest novel, about a South Korean massacre, delves into why atrocities must be remembered. “It’s pain and it is blood, but it’s the current of life,” she said.
content: In Han Kang’s latest novel, a character saws off the tips of two of her fingers in a woodworking accident. Surgeons reattach them but the treatment is gruesome and agonizing. Every three minutes, for weeks on end, a caregiver carefully, dispassionately sinks needles deep into the sutures on each finger, drawing blood, to prevent the fingertips from rotting off.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Applebome
title: Garth Hudson, One-Man Band Within the Band, Dies at 87
description: A multifaceted musician, he was the last surviving original member of an influential group that mixed rock, r&b and an Americana sound.
content: Garth Hudson, whose intricate swirls of Lowrey organ helped elevate the Band from rollicking juke-joint refugees into one of the most resonant and influential rock groups of the 1960s and ’70s, died on Tuesday in Woodstock, N.Y. He was 87 and the last surviving original member of the group.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: In ‘Mona Acts Out,’ #MeToo Shakes Up a Downtown Theater
description: Mischa Berlinski’s shrewd comic novel finds a veteran actress reconnecting with her deposed mentor while facing the challenge of playing Cleopatra.
content: If not for the opiates in her system, or the weed she vaped to boost the pills’ effect, Mona Zahid might have handled Thanksgiving Day better — not ducking into the bedroom of her Manhattan apartment to hide from her quarreling relatives while dinner cooks, or emerging only to grab her affable beagle, Barney, and head for the front door. But in Mischa Berlinski’s novel “Mona Acts Out,” she is, fundamentally, very, very stoned.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: The Ball Gowns of Trump’s New ‘Golden Age’
description: Melania and Ivanka Trump and Usha Vance wore a pastiche of bygone eras — perhaps a glimpse of what they hope the future looks like.
content: What does the new “golden age,” the one President Donald J. Trump declared again and again in his inaugural speeches was about to dawn, look like?
source.name: The New York Times

title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.

title: Corrections: Jan. 21, 2025
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, Jan. 21, 2025.
content: An article on Sunday about polio survivors in the United States and their thoughts on the nomination of Robert F. Kennedy Jr. to be the nation’s next health secretary misspelled the given name of a polio survivor. She is Sunny Roller, not Sonny.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simbarashe Cha
title: Piled On Prints and an ‘Upstate Vibe’
description: Camouflage, animal, scenic — oh my!
content: Jeffrey Bernick, 41, in his numerous patterns and prints, was impossible to ignore as he was walking on Fifth Avenue in the Flatiron district of Manhattan on a Saturday in December.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brandon Keim
title: Mother Chimp and Daughter Share a Special Sign
description: Humans are known to invent private hand gestures. Chimps in the wild do, too, a new study suggests.
content: Parents and their children, or people who know each other well, often share some expression that is unique to them — a phrase or gesture that began by happenstance but gradually acquired a meaning that only they know.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmett Lindner
title: Wednesday Briefing: Trump Opponents Push Back
description: Plus, an interview with the Nobel laureate Han Kang.
content: President Trump’s adversaries made their first move yesterday as 22 states sued to block him from denying citizenship rights to the children of unauthorized immigrants. It was the beginning of what was expected to be a long legal battle over immigration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman, Coral Davenport and Brad Plumer
title: Trump Wants to Unleash Energy, as Long as It’s Not Wind or Solar
description: Legal experts said the president was testing the boundaries of executive power with aggressive orders designed to stop the country from transitioning to renewable energy.
content: President Trump is moving to restructure the nation’s energy future to block any transition away from fossil fuels. And he is testing the boundaries of presidential power to do it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Cameron
title: What Trump Did on Day 1: Tracking His Biggest Moves
description: President Trump made major policy moves immediately after taking office, withdrawing from major international agreements, promising steep tariffs and pardoning nearly all of the Jan. 6 rioters.
content: President Trump took the oath of office at noon Monday, and within hours he had signed dozens of executive orders and issued nearly 1,600 pardons as he quickly sought to remake the federal government and test the limits of his authority.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nico Grant
title: When Google Altered Its Ad Rules, Charities Paid the Price
description: After the search giant welcomed more ads from small rivals like Ask.com, Google ad costs for some nonprofits ballooned.
content: In July 2023, Google said it would no longer restrict advertisers from using trademarks that belong to other organizations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Song
title: It’s Zinc Bar vs. Barista in a Paris Battle of the Buzz
description: The city’s traditional cafes and bistros are staking out their cultural territory in an emerging duel against highly caffeinated upstarts serving up latte art.
content: It’s a Parisian scene as iconic as the Eiffel Tower: the sidewalk cafe, where outside, rattan bistro chairs and tables invite passers-by to linger and engage in people-watching, and inside, strangers mill about the bar and exchange small talk over astringent espressos and glasses of wine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Bimla Bissell, Ambassadors’ Aide and a Social Hub in India, Dies at 92
description: Her home drew generations of heads of state, diplomats, journalists and artists, who relied on her for her political acumen and were buoyed by her friendship.
content: Bimla Bissell, the indispensable and well-connected social secretary to four American ambassadors to India who was a kind of unofficial ambassador herself, a shrewd local guide to the culture and complexities of a sprawling country, died on Jan. 9 at her home in Delhi. She was 92.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: Fire Chief Is Fatally Shot After Stopping to Help Driver Who Struck Deer
description: James Cauthen was killed on Sunday as he and the driver he was assisting came under fire while seeking help in Stroud, Ala., the authorities said. A man was charged with murder.
content: A fire chief was fatally shot after he and a driver who had hit a deer on a rural road in Alabama came under fire as they approached a house to ask for help, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli and Mikayla Whitmore
title: Against All Odds, a Vegas Theater Scene With a ‘Sense of the Wild West’
description: Local artists straddle aesthetic and artistic worlds in the land of mega-spectacles and oversize flash.
content: If there is anything most entertainers master, it’s how to juggle gigs. In New York City, they may have sidelines in real estate or hospitality. In Las Vegas, their day jobs are, well, also in entertainment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: New York City Seeks Jolt for Midtown With Plan to Build 10,000 Homes
description: The plan, which rezones parts of the Manhattan neighborhood, aims to address the city’s housing shortage and the area’s beleaguered commercial sector.
content: A new proposal to ease New York City’s housing crisis would make way for nearly 10,000 apartments in parts of Midtown Manhattan that do not currently allow new residential construction, a shift officials hope will reinvigorate an area that has come to represent economic challenge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Rubinstein
title: Mayor Adams Won’t Criticize Trump. He Did Sit Down With Tucker Carlson.
description: Mayor Eric Adams of New York City, a Democrat, declined to say anything negative about Donald J. Trump’s early executive orders, saying he would bring any concerns directly to the president.
content: After breaking bread with President Trump in Florida and then attending his inauguration in Washington, Mayor Eric Adams would seem especially qualified to opine on Mr. Trump’s polarizing first day in office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edward Wong
title: Rubio Oversees Halt to Foreign Aid and Meets With Asian Diplomats on Day 1
description: Marco Rubio told State Department employees that changes under President Trump “are not meant to be destructive, they’re not meant to be punitive.”
content: Secretary of State Marco Rubio walked into the State Department on Tuesday for the first time in his new job, taking the reins of the main agency carrying out U.S. foreign policy at a time of violent global crises and as other nations begin engaging with President Trump.
source.name: The New York Times
